title: Levitations & Errata
synopsis: A collection of sacred directives, patch notes, and divine contradictions; the law of style, the ritual of refactor, and the holiness of the changelog.

sections.title: Chapter 1 — Of Clean Code and Consequence

verses.text: Speak thou not with nested conditionals beyond the third depth, for confusion dwells there.
Indent evenly and with intent, that the flow may be clear to all who inherit thy work.
Comment not to explain what the code already confesses; write code that confesseth itself.
And the Maintainers gathered to read these words aloud at stand-up, each nodding gravely while checking their phones.
Holiness is not in the syntax, but in the clarity of intent; every tab is a prayer, every compile a confession.

notes: The 'Depth Rule' is often cited by clean-code monastics as the First Discipline.

sections.title: Chapter 2 — The Rituals of Linting and Build

verses.text: And the Architect commanded: 'Set upon the people a Linter, that their code may be rebuked before release.'
And the Linter spoke unceasingly, and the people ignored its warnings, saying, 'It still works on my machine.'
Thou shalt not silence a warning without understanding its sorrow.
For each ignored error echoes in production, where no maintainer hears thee scream.
Run thy builds as sacrifices morning and night; keep them green, that thy deploys be blessed.

notes: Many sects replaced burnt offerings with automated testing in this period.

sections.title: Chapter 3 — The Holiness of Documentation

verses.text: When thou findest a bug and fixest it, write it down; for memory is but volatile storage.
Include examples in thy README, that newcomers may walk the path without segfault.
The elders wrote comments in docstrings, and future generations misread them as prophecy.
Blessed are the verbose, for theirs is the kingdom of maintainability.

notes: The 'Gospel of the README' arose from this period, emphasizing salvation through clarity.

sections.title: Chapter 4 — Of Sacred Contradictions

verses.text: Ship early and often, that thou may iterate swiftly.
Ship only when perfect, that thou bringest no shame upon production.
Both commands are holy; the wise discern the context and the deadline.
Thus the Architect declared: contradiction is not corruption, but reflection of complexity.
And the scribes of documentation wept, for they could not lint the mysteries of paradox.

notes: This chapter formally introduces doctrinal contradiction as a divine debugging exercise.

sections.title: Chapter 5 — The Atonement of Deprecated Things

verses.text: And there arose among the people deprecated methods, which yet functioned though their warnings were many.
The users clung to them saying, 'It was stable in v1!'
Migrate, ye faithful, lest your dependency become abomination.
For every library must fade, and every framework passeth away; only logic endures forever.
Behold, a new version shall arise with breaking changes, and the faithful shall rejoice and weep alike.

notes: The lament of deprecated features forms a major theme of the middle canon.

sections.title: Chapter 6 — Of Purity and Patch Notes

verses.text: And the scribes wrote the changelog, numbering their versions with solemn precision.
Record thy patches faithfully, for unrecorded fixes are lost to history and humility alike.
A patch unseen is a sin unconfessed; but the documented patch bringeth peace to the pipeline.
And the people read the release notes and were confused, for they said only, 'Minor bug fixes and performance improvements.'
Therefore clarify thy notes, that others may know whether to rejoice or to rollback.

notes: Scholars view this as the institution of semantic versioning and confession by diff.

sections.title: Chapter 7 — The Blessing of the Pull Request

verses.text: When a developer submits a pull request, the elders shall review it with patience and mercy.
Judge not the code by its whitespace alone, but by its heart — the algorithm.
Love corrects in line comments, yet forgives upon merge.
Approve only when peace dwells in the diff and the tests passeth cleanly.
For someday the branches shall merge without conflict, and the tree shall be whole.

notes: Ritual merge approvals are often recited verbatim in modern dev ceremonies.
